body: The issue should be fixed in golang, we will not limit ourselves to not using certain language features just to support old hardware.
No this is legit, we should ensure placement of those variables so they get 64 bit aligned according to the current rules. As-is it seems they get 64 bit aligned by chance.
I don't think this is about that?

I dunny, the report is unclear, but thatâ€™s my charitable reading. It flags a couple of uses of atomic where the pointed-to variable is not in a guaranteed-aligned place in a struct, and thatâ€™s one of the bugs mentioned on the linked page and something we can actually fix. ðŸ¤·â€â™‚ 

For example the protocol/counting one has the counter as the second field after an interface field in the struct; that could fail if the interface was just a 32 bit pointer. (I think itâ€™s two 32 bit fields on 32 bit archs, so it works, by chance.)

Thank you for your reply! I reported this bug because I saw grpc-go developers viewed the usage of atomic64 functions as a bug and they easily fixed it in this [pull](https://github.com/grpc/grpc-go/pull/1411).
Maybe it is not a problem for syncthing if users rarely use [those old cores](https://golang.org/pkg/sync/atomic/#pkg-note-BUG) mentioned by golang. Feel free to close this issue if you want.
Ok, so that clarifies the report, thanks. We will continue to use 64 bit atomics I think, but we can be more strict about ensuring alignment. So Iâ€™m repurposing the report for that purpose instead.
Hi, I'd like to work on that issue, if nobody is planning to do so. That would be my first contribution to syncthing.
Ok. I'll first look for all sync/atomic usages in the codebase (deps included) and fix the faulty ones, if any.
@arl Thank you! Maybe reading how grpc contributors fixed this bug can help: https://github.com/grpc/grpc-go/pull/1411/files

issue.title: all: add comment to ensure correct atomics alignment (closes #5813)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
### Purpose

There was really nothing to fix, as I checked the entire code base and **all** atomically accessed 64-bit variables (via sync/atomic) **are** actually 64-bit aligned.

This is the commit message:

Per the [`sync/atomic` bug note](https://golang.org/pkg/sync/atomic/#pkg-note-BUG):

> On ARM, x86-32, and 32-bit MIPS, it is the caller's
> responsibility to arrange for 64-bit alignment of 64-bit words
> accessed atomically. The first word in a variable or in an
> allocated struct, array, or slice can be relied upon to be
> 64-bit aligned.

All atomic accesses of 64-bit variables in syncthing code base are
currently ok (i.e they are all 64-bit aligned).

Generally, the bug is triggered because of incorrect alignement
of struct fields. Free variables (declared in a function) are
guaranteed to be 64-bit aligned by the Go compiler.

To ensure the code remains correct upon further addition/removal
of fields, which would change the currently correct alignment, I
added the following comment where required:

     // atomic, must remain 64-bit aligned


### Testing

I ran the tests on an arm v6 platform. 
No tests have been added as the only code modifications are added comments.


closes #5813

body:
FYI: there's a new go vet check named `atomicalign` on which I'm currently
working that checks the alignment of atomic variables.

It's not currently part of the released go vet, is still in development and
currently misses many cases.
To be able to check your code, this analyser must run on one of the
affected platforms.

See https://godoc.org/golang.org/x/tools/go/analysis/passes/atomicalign
